elements.content: In recent years, the irrational use of antibiotics has become very widespread. It is necessary to regulate this phenomenon through antibiotic detection. In this work, a series of isomorphic Ln-MOFs (Ln = Tb3+ and Eu3+) were synthesized from 1,3,5-tri­(4-carboxyphenyl)­benzene (H3L) and Ln3+ by the solvothermal method for the first time. A series of 1-Eu x Tb 1–x with different luminescence were doped by changing the molar ratio of Tb3+ and Eu3+. Ln3+ forms a 4-connected 2D network structure through self-assembly with fully deprotonated L3–. It shows good chemical stability in water, and its luminescence is not affected by aqueous solutions with different pH values. 1-Eu demonstrates rapid and sensitive detection capabilities for MDZ and TET with good recyclability and low detection limits (10–5). In order to increase the practicability of 1-Eu, two portable sensors have been prepared, in which the fluorescent film (Film@1-Eu) has a detection limit of 10–4, and the sensitivity is only less than 10% of the titration results. A portable fluorescent test paper can reach the detection limit of 14.7 ppm. This study provides a new idea for the application of stable multifunctional materials in the field of fluorescence sensing.

elements.content: A series of 2D fluorescent Ln-MOFs were first obtained in this work. The antibiotic sensing experiments show that 1-Eu has a significant quenching effect on MDZ and TET. Two kinds of fluorescence sensors were prepared for simplifying the application of 1-Eu in the sensing field. This work may provide a facile and reliable method for Ln-MOFs to be better applied in the field of fluorescence sensing.

elements.content: It is crucial to develop new materials and diversify their applications in order to keep up with the new global trend in science and technology development. In recent decades, researchers have made satisfactory achievements in coordination chemistry, which has broken the boundary between traditional inorganic chemistry and organic chemistry. Since their discovery, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been widely studied in the fields of gas adsorption and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, biological imaging, fluorescence sensing, and so forth. Among them, lanthanide MOFs (Ln-MOFs) have many remarkable characteristics, such as narrow emission band, significant Stoke shift, diverse host–guest interactions, high quantum yield, special luminescent color, and so on. It is well known that the f–f transition of Ln3+ is forbidden. However, the coupling effect (luminescence sensitization or antenna effect) can realize energy transfer. Thus, Ln3+ can attain effective luminescence. Therefore, the application of Ln-MOF materials (anti-counterfeiting, intelligent logic devices, etc.) has attracted great attention in the optical field.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

It is crucial to develop new materials and diversify their applications in order to keep up with the new global trend in science and technology development. In recent decades, researchers have made satisfactory achievements in coordination chemistry, which has broken the boundary between traditional inorganic chemistry and organic chemistry. Since their discovery, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been widely studied in the fields of gas adsorption and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, biological imaging, fluorescence sensing, and so forth. Among them, lanthanide MOFs (Ln-MOFs) have many remarkable characteristics, such as narrow emission band, significant Stoke shift, diverse host-guest interactions, high quantum yield, special luminescent color, and so on. It is well known that the f-f transition of Ln3+ is forbidden. However, the coupling effect (luminescence sensitization or antenna effect) can realize energy transfer. Thus, Ln3+ can attain effective luminescence. Therefore, the application of Ln-MOF materials (anti-counterfeiting, intelligent logic devices, etc.) has attracted great attention in the optical field.

elements.content: As a new pollutant, pharmaceutical and personal care products (PPCPs) have attracted increasing attention. Due to the long shelf life of PPCPs, they can still exist for a long time after entering the external environment. The results show that PPCPs mostly exist in pharmaceutical wastewater, groundwater, rivers, and lakes in trace concentrations. Antibiotics belong to the series of medicines in PPCPs, in which metronidazole (MDZ) and tetracycline (TET) are used to prevent and treat infections. MDZ is a derivative of nitroimidazole, which plays an important role in the resistance to anaerobes. However, large doses of MDZ can cause convulsions in clinic. TET has been used to treat bacterial infections in humans and animals for a long time. But the overuse of TET has led to the emergence of drug-resistant strains in recent years. Therefore, the rapid and sensitive detection of antibiotics from different samples has great significance in drinking water and food safety. Traditional antibiotic detection methods include high-performance liquid chromatography, spectrophotometry, mass spectrometry, capillary electrophoresis, chemiluminescence, and so forth, which are not only costly and time consuming but even have strict requirements on instruments and samples. Therefore, it is very important to develop a fast, sensitive, low-cost, and convenient sensor for detecting antibiotics.

elements.content: Because of its high sensitivity, low cost, and simple operation, fluorescence sensing technology has become a research hotspot in the field of chemistry, paving the way for intelligent sensing. Generally, fluorescence sensing is realized by fluorescence quenching or enhancement, which can be used to measure analyte qualitatively or quantitatively. Ln-MOFs have not only obvious color but also multiple fluorescence responses. They are expected to be a new luminescent material that produce a fluorescence response after the introduction of target analytes. At the same time, portable sensor probes (such as fluorescent sensor films, hydrogel sensors, paper-based sensors based on smartphone, etc.) as field analysis technology are very popular in the real-time analysis of target analytes and visual monitoring.

Generally, fluorescence sensing is realized by fluorescence quenching or enhancement, which can be used to measure analyte qualitatively or quantitatively. Ln-MOFs have not only obvious color but also multiple fluorescence responses. They are expected to be a new luminescent material that produce a fluorescence response after the introduction of target analytes. At the same time, portable sensor probes (such as fluorescent sensor films, hydrogel sensors, paper-based sensors based on smartphone, etc.) as field analysis technology are very popular in the real-time analysis of target analytes and visual monitoring.

elements.content: Inspired by the above factors, 1,3,5-tri­(4-carboxyphenyl)­benzene (H3L) was designed and chosen as multiple coordination sites to construct two isomorphic two-dimensional (2D) Ln-MOFs {[Ln2(L)2(NMP) (H2O)3]·3NMP·2H2O}n (Ln = Tb3+ and Eu3+) with permanent porosity under solvothermal conditions. Among them, 1-Eu has strong red luminescence and 1-Tb has green luminescence. By changing the molar ratio of Eu3+/Tb3+ ions, a series of 1-Eu x Tb 1–x complexes with different fluorescence colors can be obtained. At the same time, 1-Ln can be successfully used to detect antibiotics MDZ and TET by fluorescence quenching. In this regard, we propose three methods for fluorescence analysis: the first is fluorescence analysis in solution. 1-Eu can sensitively and effectively detect MDZ and TET in water and blood, with detection lines of 10–5 mol L–1. The second is fluorescence analysis based on the fluorescent film. A polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) film (Film@1-Eu) has been successfully prepared (), which can be rapidly quenched in MDZ and TET. The fluorescence can be restored after simple washing. It is a fluorescent sensor with high recyclability, and its sensitivity is only lower than 10% of the detection effect in solution. The third is the fluorescence analysis of a portable test paper based on a smartphone. Under the irradiation of UV light, the test paper shows different colors in different concentrations of MDZ, and the smartphone can semi-quantitatively analyze MDZ by reading the corresponding R (red), G (green), and B (blue) values. Therefore, 1-Ln is expected to develop into a promising fluorescent-sensing material.

elements.content:
All the chemical reagents used in experiments were purchased commercially. The characterization methods are mentioned in the Supporting Information.

Preparation of <bold>Film@1-Eu</bold>

In this process, we introduced a kind of adhesive PTFE. First, 1-Eu was ground into powder and placed on a smooth glass plate. Then, some PTFE was dripped on the powder, and the EtOH was added in proportion to control its viscosity. After that, the mixture was stirred slowly in the same direction until it formed a gel, and then, it was flattened with a glass rod. Finally, a fluorescence test film (Film@1-Eu) was formed naturally after drying.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the chemical reagents used in experiments were purchased commercially. The characterization methods are mentioned in the Supporting Information.

Preparation of Film@1-Eu 

In this process, we introduced a kind of adhesive PTFE. First, 1-Eu was ground into powder and placed on a smooth glass plate. Then, some PTFE was dripped on the powder, and the EtOH was added in proportion to control its viscosity. After that, the mixture was stirred slowly in the same direction until it formed a gel, and then, it was flattened with a glass rod. Finally, a fluorescence test film (Film@1-Eu) was formed naturally after drying.

elements.content: Using the prepared 1-Eu as a fluorescent probe, the visual semi-quantification analysis of MDZ and TET was carried out. First, the quantitative filter paper was cut into 1 cm × 1 cm square pieces, and 1-Eu was ground into powder and uniformly dispersed in the aqueous solution of MDZ with different concentrations. It was treated with ultrasound for 10 min to ensure that the crystal powder was evenly dispersed on the filter paper. In the presence of MDZ, the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu on the test paper was gradually quenched. The red fluorescence of 1-Eu progressively declined as the concentrations of MDZ increased. The emission of the test papers was recorded under UV light (365 nm), and photos were taken with a smartphone. The RGB values were measured by the Color Picker software, and the calibration curves of a red channel were drawn.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of a Strip Test Paper for Visual Inspection

Using the prepared 1-Eu as a fluorescent probe, the visual semi-quantification analysis of MDZ and TET was carried out. First, the quantitative filter paper was cut into 1 cm × 1 cm square pieces, and 1-Eu was ground into powder and uniformly dispersed in the aqueous solution of MDZ with different concentrations. It was treated with ultrasound for 10 min to ensure that the crystal powder was evenly dispersed on the filter paper. In the presence of MDZ, the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu on the test paper was gradually quenched. The red fluorescence of 1-Eu progressively declined as the concentrations of MDZ increased. The emission of the test papers was recorded under UV light (365 nm), and photos were taken with a smartphone. The RGB values were measured by the Color Picker software, and the calibration curves of a red channel were drawn.

elements.content: The crystallographic data of 1-Ln are given in . The X-ray single crystal diffractometry shows that the complexes 1-Tb and 1-Eu are isomorphic two-dimensional (2D) networks. Structural analysis exhibits that 1-Eu crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit includes two independent Eu3+ centers, two fully deprotonated L3–, three coordinated H2O molecules, one coordinated NMP molecule, two guest H2O, and three dissociative NMP (a). With four Eu3+ ions, the carboxylate group of the L3– ligand adopts the bidentate bridge (η2μ2χ2) and bidentate chelating (η2μ1χ2) coordination modes (Figure S1). However, Eu3+ ions are surrounded by eight O atoms, forming a distorted tetrakaidecahedron geometry (b). Among them, the center of Eu1 is coordinated with six carboxylate oxygen atoms from four L3– and two O atoms of H2O and NMP molecules, respectively. Eu2 is surrounded by six oxygen atoms of four L3–, and the two O atoms are connected by two H2O molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

The crystallographic data of 1-Ln are given in . The X-ray single crystal diffractometry shows that the complexes 1-Tb and 1-Eu are isomorphic two-dimensional (2D) networks. Structural analysis exhibits that 1-Eu crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit includes two independent Eu3+ centers, two fully deprotonated L3-, three coordinated H2O molecules, one coordinated NMP molecule, two guest H2O, and three dissociative NMP (a). With four Eu3+ ions, the carboxylate group of the L3- ligand adopts the bidentate bridge (η2μ2χ2) and bidentate chelating (η2μ1χ2) coordination modes (Figure S1). However, Eu3+ ions are surrounded by eight O atoms, forming a distorted tetrakaidecahedron geometry (b). Among them, the center of Eu1 is coordinated with six carboxylate oxygen atoms from four L3- and two O atoms of H2O and NMP molecules, respectively. Eu2 is surrounded by six oxygen atoms of four L3-, and the two O atoms are connected by two H2O molecules.

elements.content: The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) of 1-Ln and 1-Eu x Tb 1–x is consistent with the simulated peaks, indicating that the duplicated samples are pure phase, which can be used for subsequent property exploration (Figure S3). 1-Ln was heated from 30 to 800 °C for thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in a N2 atmosphere. 1-Ln had similar thermal stability due to its isostructural properties, and 1-Eu was taken as an example to analyze in detail. The TGA of 1-Eu showed that weight loss was 31.3% (calcd 31.5%) between 35 and 309 °C, possibly attributed to the free solvent molecules and the coordinated water molecules being removed. The frame structure existed stably between 309 and 550 °C, then the frameworks collapsed (Figures S3c and S4).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Powder Diffraction and Thermogravimetric Analysis

The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) of 1-Ln and 1-Eu   x   Tb  1-x   is consistent with the simulated peaks, indicating that the duplicated samples are pure phase, which can be used for subsequent property exploration (Figure S3). 1-Ln was heated from 30 to 800 °C for thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in a N2 atmosphere. 1-Ln had similar thermal stability due to its isostructural properties, and 1-Eu was taken as an example to analyze in detail. The TGA of 1-Eu showed that weight loss was 31.3% (calcd 31.5%) between 35 and 309 °C, possibly attributed to the free solvent molecules and the coordinated water molecules being removed. The frame structure existed stably between 309 and 550 °C, then the frameworks collapsed (Figures S3c and S4).

elements.content: Since antibiotics can exist in water in any pH environment, the stability of 1-Eu at different pH values was investigated. The PXRD of 1-Eu was measured after soaking it in an aqueous solution with a pH of 2–11 for 24 h. The skeleton of 1-Eu remains intact, which proves its stability at different pH values (Figure S5). As shown in Figure S6, the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu is hardly affected by pH. Therefore, it can be seen that 1-Eu can still maintain stable red fluorescence at different pH values.
elements.clean_text:
pH Stability

Since antibiotics can exist in water in any pH environment, the stability of 1-Eu at different pH values was investigated. The PXRD of 1-Eu was measured after soaking it in an aqueous solution with a pH of 2-11 for 24 h. The skeleton of 1-Eu remains intact, which proves its stability at different pH values (Figure S5). As shown in Figure S6, the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu is hardly affected by pH. Therefore, it can be seen that 1-Eu can still maintain stable red fluorescence at different pH values.

elements.content: The solid-state photoluminescence properties have been studied for the H3L ligand and 1-Ln complexes under ambient conditions. The photoluminescence spectra of the H3L ligand revealed the maximum (Figure S7) mission at 404 nm (λex = 343 nm), attributed to the electron transition of π → π* after absorbing energy (). The luminescence of 1-Ln was restricted to the selection of f–f transition and the luminescence achieved by the “antenna effect” of the organic ligands. Complex 1-Tb excited at 334 nm displays narrow peaks at 489 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 544 nm (5D4 → 7F5) (strong), 582 nm (5D4 → 7F4), and 618 nm (5D4 → 7F3), corresponding to the electronic transition of 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6–3) of Tb3+ ions. Thus, 1-Tb showed a strong green fluorescence emission. Based on electron transitions of 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, and 5D0 → 7F4, 1-Eu exhibited characteristic peaks of Eu3+ at 592, 616, and 695 nm, respectively (λex = 338 nm). The relative intensities of the 5D0 → 7F2 and 5D0 → 7F1 transitions are used to measure the coordination state (a). Considering the feeble symmetry of Eu3+ at 5D0 → 7F1, the intensity of the magnetic dipole transition was weak. The intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition allowed the electric dipole transition to increase, forming a sharp emission spectrum. On the contrary, a less intense wide peak was observed in the 5D0 → 7F4 transition (695 nm) (b). The single exponential decay of 1-Tb and 1-Eu were 473.75 and 365.29 μs, respectively (Figure S8). Compared with 1-Eu, the relatively lower lifetime of 1-Tb was mainly the result of the different sensitivities of these ions quenched by O–H.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Fluorescence Properties of 1-Ln 

The solid-state photoluminescence properties have been studied for the H3L ligand and 1-Ln complexes under ambient conditions. The photoluminescence spectra of the H3L ligand revealed the maximum (Figure S7) mission at 404 nm (λex  = 343 nm), attributed to the electron transition of π → π* after absorbing energy (). The luminescence of 1-Ln was restricted to the selection of f-f transition and the luminescence achieved by the "antenna effect" of the organic ligands. Complex 1-Tb excited at 334 nm displays narrow peaks at 489 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 544 nm (5D4 → 7F5) (strong), 582 nm (5D4 → 7F4), and 618 nm (5D4 → 7F3), corresponding to the electronic transition of 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6-3) of Tb3+ ions. Thus, 1-Tb showed a strong green fluorescence emission. Based on electron transitions of 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, and 5D0 → 7F4, 1-Eu exhibited characteristic peaks of Eu3+ at 592, 616, and 695 nm, respectively (λex  = 338 nm). The relative intensities of the 5D0 → 7F2 and 5D0 → 7F1 transitions are used to measure the coordination state (a). Considering the feeble symmetry of Eu3+ at 5D0 → 7F1, the intensity of the magnetic dipole transition was weak. The intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition allowed the electric dipole transition to increase, forming a sharp emission spectrum. On the contrary, a less intense wide peak was observed in the 5D0 → 7F4 transition (695 nm) (b). The single exponential decay of 1-Tb and 1-Eu were 473.75 and 365.29 μs, respectively (Figure S8). Compared with 1-Eu, the relatively lower lifetime of 1-Tb was mainly the result of the different sensitivities of these ions quenched by O-H.

elements.content: As the synthesized 1-Eu and 1-Tb are isomorphic, a series of doped 1-Eu x Tb 1–x with color luminescence were successfully synthesized by adjusting the molar ratio of Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions in the complex. The gradual transition from green to red is observed under the 365 nm UV lamp excitation (a). The chromaticity coordinates are calculated and plotted in CIE coordinates (b). The corresponding CIE coordinates range from (0.29, 0.61) to (0.67, 0.33), showing the emission color more clearly (). It is worth noting that 1-Eu x Tb 1–x shows double emissions of Eu3+ and Tb3+. The emission peak indicates a significant red shift when the proportion of Eu3+ increases from 2 to 90% (c). The results indicate that the energy of Ln3+ ions can be transferred by doping other ions. The fluorescence intensity of 1-Tb is decreased by increasing the molar ratio of Eu3+ ions, indicating that the energy is transferred. Meanwhile, the corresponding absolute quantum yield of 1-Eu (10.1%) is lower than 1-Tb (34.4%), which further proves that the energy transfer process is effective (Table S2). The energy transfer efficiency ηT of ions from Tb3+ to Eu3+ in a series of doped 1-Eu x Tb 1–x may be computed using the formula ηT = 1 – τ/τ0 (where τ and τ0 represent the lifetime of Tb3+ before/after doping Eu3+, respectively) (d).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Modulation of 1-Eu x Tb1- x  

As the synthesized 1-Eu and 1-Tb are isomorphic, a series of doped 1-Eu   x   Tb  1-x   with color luminescence were successfully synthesized by adjusting the molar ratio of Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions in the complex. The gradual transition from green to red is observed under the 365 nm UV lamp excitation (a). The chromaticity coordinates are calculated and plotted in CIE coordinates (b). The corresponding CIE coordinates range from (0.29, 0.61) to (0.67, 0.33), showing the emission color more clearly (). It is worth noting that 1-Eu   x   Tb  1-x   shows double emissions of Eu3+ and Tb3+. The emission peak indicates a significant red shift when the proportion of Eu3+ increases from 2 to 90% (c). The results indicate that the energy of Ln3+ ions can be transferred by doping other ions. The fluorescence intensity of 1-Tb is decreased by increasing the molar ratio of Eu3+ ions, indicating that the energy is transferred. Meanwhile, the corresponding absolute quantum yield of 1-Eu (10.1%) is lower than 1-Tb (34.4%), which further proves that the energy transfer process is effective (Table S2). The energy transfer efficiency ηT of ions from Tb3+ to Eu3+ in a series of doped 1-Eu   x   Tb  1-x   may be computed using the formula ηT = 1 - τ/τ0 (where τ and τ0 represent the lifetime of Tb3+ before/after doping Eu3+, respectively) (d).

1-Eu has stable red emission and excellent water stability (Figure S9a); hence, the fluorescence sensing of drugs in water by 1-Eu was studied. Eight common antibioticsSM2 (sulfadimidine), SMZ (sulfamethoxazole), AMX (amoxicillin), SFZ (sulfadiazine), FFC (florfenicol), ERM (erythromycin), MDZ, and TET (Scheme S1)­()were selected in this experiment. 3 mg 1-Eu was added into 3 mL aqueous solution of different drugs (1 × 10–3 mol/L); then, it was ultrasonicated for 10 min to form uniform suspensions and the fluorescence spectra of different drugs were measured. The results show that the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu is significantly quenched in MDZ and TET, and the quenching efficiencies are up to 99.8 and 99.9%, respectively. For other drugs, the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu also decreased to different degrees ( and S10).
elements.clean_text:
Selective Sensing of Antibiotics

 1-Eu has stable red emission and excellent water stability (Figure S9a); hence, the fluorescence sensing of drugs in water by 1-Eu was studied. Eight common antibioticsSM2 (sulfadimidine), SMZ (sulfamethoxazole), AMX (amoxicillin), SFZ (sulfadiazine), FFC (florfenicol), ERM (erythromycin), MDZ, and TET (Scheme S1)()were selected in this experiment. 3 mg 1-Eu was added into 3 mL aqueous solution of different drugs (1 × 10-3 mol/L); then, it was ultrasonicated for 10 min to form uniform suspensions and the fluorescence spectra of different drugs were measured. The results show that the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu is significantly quenched in MDZ and TET, and the quenching efficiencies are up to 99.8 and 99.9%, respectively. For other drugs, the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu also decreased to different degrees ( and S10).

elements.content: (a) Spectra of 1-Eu in diverse antibiotic solutions; (b) relative fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu in diverse antibiotic solutions.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Spectra of 1-Eu in diverse antibiotic solutions; (b) relative fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu in diverse antibiotic solutions.

elements.content: In order to detect the sensitivity of 1-Eu to MDZ and TET, the blank water samples were titrated with MDZ and TET, respectively, and the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu after each titration was recorded. The result indicates that the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu decreases with the increase in the concentrations of MDZ and TET. The fluorescence of 1-Eu is completely quenched when TET and MDZ are at concentrations of 0.348 and 0.306 mM, respectively (a,b). According to Stern–Volmer (SV) equation (I 0/I = 1 + K sv [M]), it is possible to calculate quantitatively the quenching efficiency (I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after the addition of MDZ or TET, K sv is the quenching constant (M–1), and [M] is the concentration of MDZ or TET, respectively). The SV equation is used to determine the relationship between the concentration of MDZ or TET and fluorescence intensity. In the low-concentration range from 0 to 0.06 mM, the SV curve of MDZ or TET is virtually linearly connected. But the SV curve gradually deviates from the linear relationship with the increase in the antibiotic concentration (c,d). The nonlinear relationship of the SV curve may be attributed to energy transfer or the self-absorption of antibiotics. According to the fitting results, the K sv values of MDZ and TET are 1.5 × 104 and 1.45 × 104 M–1, respectively. Therefore, 1-Eu can be used as a promising fluorescent probe to detect MDZ and TET. According to the formula 3σ/K sv (σ is the standard deviation), the limit of detection (LOD) of MDZ and TET is 1.46 × 10–5 and 1.51 × 10–5 M, respectively, which are almost equivalent to those reported in the literature (Table S3).

elements.content: In order to evaluate the anti-interference ability of 1-Eu, 1-Eu was dispersed in an aqueous solution containing SM2, SMZ, AMX, SFZ, FFC, and ERM, and the fluorescence intensity remained unchanged under the excitation of 338 nm. However, when MDZ or TET was added, the fluorescence intensity decreased obviously, which indicates that 1-Eu can selectively quench MDZ and TET in water (a and S11). As we all know, antibiotics enter the blood circulation for anti-infection treatment after intravenous injection. Therefore, the anti-interference experiment of 1-Eu on the possible coexisting components (Mg2+, Ca2+, Zn2+, K+, Na+, CO3 2–, Glu, Urea, l-valine, l-histidine) in the simulated blood shows that the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu is almost unchanged at the same excitation wavelength. But it obviously decreases when MDZ or TET is added, which indicates that the interfering components in simulated blood has little effect on MDZ or TET (b and S12). The 1-Eu sample can be recovered from the solution by washing with water and centrifugation, and the fluorescence intensity of the regenerated sample is the same as that of the original sample. After five cycles, the PXRD of the regenerated sample is determined, which indicates that the framework of 1-Eu is still intact (Figure S13). Experiments make it clear that 1-Eu shows good stability and recyclability in the field of selective detection (Figure S14).

elements.content: To further explore the quenching effect of 1-Eu for MDZ and TET, we studied the quenching mechanism of 1-Eu. The PXRD of 1-Eu was tested by soaking it in different antibiotic solutions. The results show that the structure of 1-Eu is intact, which proves that the fluorescence quenching is not caused by structural collapse (Figure S9b). In addition, the fluorescence lifetime with or without antibiotics is recorded at 617 nm. With the addition of MDZ and TET, the fluorescence lifetime decreases, which indicates that there is dynamic quenching (a).
elements.clean_text:
Sensing Mechanism

To further explore the quenching effect of 1-Eu for MDZ and TET, we studied the quenching mechanism of 1-Eu. The PXRD of 1-Eu was tested by soaking it in different antibiotic solutions. The results show that the structure of 1-Eu is intact, which proves that the fluorescence quenching is not caused by structural collapse (Figure S9b). In addition, the fluorescence lifetime with or without antibiotics is recorded at 617 nm. With the addition of MDZ and TET, the fluorescence lifetime decreases, which indicates that there is dynamic quenching (a).

elements.content: The typical photoinduced electron transfer (PET) system is to explore whether fluorescence quenching is caused by PET process. If the highest occupied molecular (HOMO) or lowest unoccupied molecular (LUMO) orbit of antibiotics is between the energies of the two orbits of fluorophore (H3L ligand), PET will proceed. The LUMO and HOMO energies of antibiotics in water were calculated by density functional theory (DET). Specifically, the HOMO orbit of antibiotic (SM2, SMZ, AMX, SFZ, ERM, TET) is between the two orbits of H3L, which can transfer the HOMO electrons to the excited state. And H3L makes the excited electrons unable to jump back to the original ground state to emit fluorescence, which leads to the decrease of fluorescence intensity in different degrees. It is consistent with the experimental results. The LUMO and HOMO of MDZ are between the two orbits of H3L. After H3L is excited by light, one electron of its HOMO jumps to LUMO. The electron turns into the empty LUMO orbit of MDZ and then returns to the HOMO orbit of H3L, which provides another way for the excited electron to return to the ground state by non-radiation. Thus, the fluorescence of 1-Eu is quenched ( and Table S4).

elements.content: Another factor that contributes to fluorescence quenching is the resonance energy transfer. As shown in b, the excitation spectrum of 1-Eu completely overlaps with the UV absorption peak of MDZ and mostly overlaps with that of TET. Therefore, there is competitive absorption between 1-Eu, MDZ, and TET, which leads to fluorescence quenching.

elements.content: The above experiments prove that 1-Eu has excellent fluorescence-sensing performance. In order to simplify the application potential of 1-Eu in sense, we successfully prepared a fluorescent film (Film@1-Eu) loaded with 1-Eu, which can be used to quickly and conveniently detect antibiotics in pharmaceutical wastewater. The prepared fluorescent test films were put in water, MDZ, and TET and irradiated with a 365 nm UV light. The results showed that the red fluorescence of Film@1-Eu disappeared immediately in the solution of MDZ and TET, but remained stable in water (a). The color change makes Film@1-Eu a promising luminescence sensor. Due to the instantaneous quenching of 1-Eu luminescence, MDZ and TET can be quickly detected by the naked eye. Moreover, the fluorescence of Film@1-Eu can be recovered by simple washing, which proves that it has strong recyclability.
elements.clean_text:
Film@1-Eu for Antibiotic Sensing

The above experiments prove that 1-Eu has excellent fluorescence-sensing performance. In order to simplify the application potential of 1-Eu in sense, we successfully prepared a fluorescent film (Film@1-Eu) loaded with 1-Eu, which can be used to quickly and conveniently detect antibiotics in pharmaceutical wastewater. The prepared fluorescent test films were put in water, MDZ, and TET and irradiated with a 365 nm UV light. The results showed that the red fluorescence of Film@1-Eu disappeared immediately in the solution of MDZ and TET, but remained stable in water (a). The color change makes Film@1-Eu a promising luminescence sensor. Due to the instantaneous quenching of 1-Eu luminescence, MDZ and TET can be quickly detected by the naked eye. Moreover, the fluorescence of Film@1-Eu can be recovered by simple washing, which proves that it has strong recyclability.

elements.content: (a) Photos of Film@1-Eu irradiated with UV light; (b) Film@1-Eu immersed in different pH for 40 days; (c) Film@1-Eu immersed in different antibiotics; (d) comparison of luminescence intensity of Film@1-Eu in different antibiotics.
elements.clean_text: 10  (a) Photos of Film@1-Eu irradiated with UV light; (b) Film@1-Eu immersed in different pH for 40 days; (c) Film@1-Eu immersed in different antibiotics; (d) comparison of luminescence intensity of Film@1-Eu in different antibiotics.

elements.content: The experimental results show that the visual detection limit of Film@1-Eu for MDZ and TET can reach 10–4 mol L–1, which is only about 10% lower than the titration result (10–5 mol L–1). Compared with experimental titration, this method is simpler and easier to operate. The Film@1-Eu was soaked in different pH (4, 7, 10) solution, and after soaking for 40 days, the Film@1-Eu was irradiated with 365 nm UV light to keep the stable red light (b). The result is better than those of some published literature studies. In addition, Film@1-Eu was soaked in several other antibiotic solutions, which could keep the stable red light (c,d). The above experimental results show that Film@1-Eu can be used as a fluorescent sensor with high sensitivity to MDZ and TET.

elements.content: The paper sensor has the advantages of high practicability, low cost, and fast detection. Thus, it can be used for the identification and semi-quantitative detection of analytes. The prepared 1-Eu was used as a fluorescent probe to realize semi-quantitative detection of MDZ. The test strips were soaked in different concentrations of MDZ, and the red fluorescence of 1-Eu on the test strips was gradually quenched with the increase in concentration. Photos of test strips were taken with smartphones, and their RGB values were measured with the Color Picker software. In order to minimize the error, calibration curves were made between the red channel and MDZ concentrations after multiple readings. As shown in , with the increase of MDZ concentration, the color of the test paper gradually changes from bright pink to dark purple, and the value of B/R increases correspondingly, showing a good linear correlation (R 2 = 0.994). According to 3σ/slope, the LOD value of the detection limit is 14.7 ppm. Therefore, the paper sensor has potential application value in the rapid and sensitive detection of analytes.
elements.clean_text:
Visual Detection of the Portable Test Paper Based on Smartphones

The paper sensor has the advantages of high practicability, low cost, and fast detection. Thus, it can be used for the identification and semi-quantitative detection of analytes. The prepared 1-Eu was used as a fluorescent probe to realize semi-quantitative detection of MDZ. The test strips were soaked in different concentrations of MDZ, and the red fluorescence of 1-Eu on the test strips was gradually quenched with the increase in concentration. Photos of test strips were taken with smartphones, and their RGB values were measured with the Color Picker software. In order to minimize the error, calibration curves were made between the red channel and MDZ concentrations after multiple readings. As shown in , with the increase of MDZ concentration, the color of the test paper gradually changes from bright pink to dark purple, and the value of B/R increases correspondingly, showing a good linear correlation (R 2 = 0.994). According to 3σ/slope, the LOD value of the detection limit is 14.7 ppm. Therefore, the paper sensor has potential application value in the rapid and sensitive detection of analytes.

elements.content: Visual detection of a portable test paper based on smartphones.
elements.clean_text: 11  Visual detection of a portable test paper based on smartphones.

elements.content: In summary, 2D porous Ln-MOFs were constructed by rigid ligands H3L and Ln3+ ions. The 1-Ln complexes have excellent chemical stability and luminescent properties; especially 1-Eu can be used to selectively detect MDZ and TET in antibiotics and blood, which proves that 1-Eu can be used as a sensitive fluorescent probe. In the aspect of sensor application, 1-Eu was made into a fluorescent sensing film (Film@1-Eu), which shows the ideal detection limits (10–4) for MDZ and TET. Especially, the luminescence of Film@1-Eu can be recovered by simple washing with water, which indicates that it has good recyclability. In addition, 1-Eu is made into a portable paper sensor for the quantitative detection of MDZ in antibiotics, and the reliable detection limit (14.7 ppm) and linear range can be calculated by a smartphone platform. In short, making 1-Eu into various sensors is a reliable method that tends to meet all kinds of tests.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, 2D porous Ln-MOFs were constructed by rigid ligands H3L and Ln3+ ions. The 1-Ln complexes have excellent chemical stability and luminescent properties; especially 1-Eu can be used to selectively detect MDZ and TET in antibiotics and blood, which proves that 1-Eu can be used as a sensitive fluorescent probe. In the aspect of sensor application, 1-Eu was made into a fluorescent sensing film (Film@1-Eu), which shows the ideal detection limits (10-4) for MDZ and TET. Especially, the luminescence of Film@1-Eu can be recovered by simple washing with water, which indicates that it has good recyclability. In addition, 1-Eu is made into a portable paper sensor for the quantitative detection of MDZ in antibiotics, and the reliable detection limit (14.7 ppm) and linear range can be calculated by a smartphone platform. In short, making 1-Eu into various sensors is a reliable method that tends to meet all kinds of tests.

cln_elements.content:
The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) of 1-Ln and 1-Eu x Tb 1–x is consistent with the simulated peaks, indicating that the duplicated samples are pure phase, which can be used for subsequent property exploration (Figure S3). 1-Ln was heated from 30 to 800 °C for thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in a N2 atmosphere. 1-Ln had similar thermal stability due to its isostructural properties, and 1-Eu was taken as an example to analyze in detail. The TGA of 1-Eu showed that weight loss was 31.3% (calcd 31.5%) between 35 and 309 °C, possibly attributed to the free solvent molecules and the coordinated water molecules being removed. The frame structure existed stably between 309 and 550 °C, then the frameworks collapsed (Figures S3c and S4).

Solid-State Fluorescence Properties of <bold>1-Ln</bold>

The solid-state photoluminescence properties have been studied for the H3L ligand and 1-Ln complexes under ambient conditions. The photoluminescence spectra of the H3L ligand revealed the maximum (Figure S7) mission at 404 nm (λex = 343 nm), attributed to the electron transition of π → π* after absorbing energy (). The luminescence of 1-Ln was restricted to the selection of f–f transition and the luminescence achieved by the “antenna effect” of the organic ligands. Complex 1-Tb excited at 334 nm displays narrow peaks at 489 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 544 nm (5D4 → 7F5) (strong), 582 nm (5D4 → 7F4), and 618 nm (5D4 → 7F3), corresponding to the electronic transition of 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6–3) of Tb3+ ions. Thus, 1-Tb showed a strong green fluorescence emission. Based on electron transitions of 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, and 5D0 → 7F4, 1-Eu exhibited characteristic peaks of Eu3+ at 592, 616, and 695 nm, respectively (λex = 338 nm). The relative intensities of the 5D0 → 7F2 and 5D0 → 7F1 transitions are used to measure the coordination state (a). Considering the feeble symmetry of Eu3+ at 5D0 → 7F1, the intensity of the magnetic dipole transition was weak. The intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition allowed the electric dipole transition to increase, forming a sharp emission spectrum. On the contrary, a less intense wide peak was observed in the 5D0 → 7F4 transition (695 nm) (b). The single exponential decay of 1-Tb and 1-Eu were 473.75 and 365.29 μs, respectively (Figure S8). Compared with 1-Eu, the relatively lower lifetime of 1-Tb was mainly the result of the different sensitivities of these ions quenched by O–H.

Luminescence Modulation of 1-Eu<sub> <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> </sub>Tb<sub>1<bold>–</bold> <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> </sub>

As the synthesized 1-Eu and 1-Tb are isomorphic, a series of doped 1-Eu x Tb 1–x with color luminescence were successfully synthesized by adjusting the molar ratio of Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions in the complex. The gradual transition from green to red is observed under the 365 nm UV lamp excitation (a). The chromaticity coordinates are calculated and plotted in CIE coordinates (b). The corresponding CIE coordinates range from (0.29, 0.61) to (0.67, 0.33), showing the emission color more clearly (). It is worth noting that 1-Eu x Tb 1–x shows double emissions of Eu3+ and Tb3+. The emission peak indicates a significant red shift when the proportion of Eu3+ increases from 2 to 90% (c). The results indicate that the energy of Ln3+ ions can be transferred by doping other ions. The fluorescence intensity of 1-Tb is decreased by increasing the molar ratio of Eu3+ ions, indicating that the energy is transferred. Meanwhile, the corresponding absolute quantum yield of 1-Eu (10.1%) is lower than 1-Tb (34.4%), which further proves that the energy transfer process is effective (Table S2). The energy transfer efficiency ηT of ions from Tb3+ to Eu3+ in a series of doped 1-Eu x Tb 1–x may be computed using the formula ηT = 1 – τ/τ0 (where τ and τ0 represent the lifetime of Tb3+ before/after doping Eu3+, respectively) (d).

Selective Sensing of Antibiotics

1-Eu has stable red emission and excellent water stability (Figure S9a); hence, the fluorescence sensing of drugs in water by 1-Eu was studied. Eight common antibioticsSM2 (sulfadimidine), SMZ (sulfamethoxazole), AMX (amoxicillin), SFZ (sulfadiazine), FFC (florfenicol), ERM (erythromycin), MDZ, and TET (Scheme S1)­()were selected in this experiment. 3 mg 1-Eu was added into 3 mL aqueous solution of different drugs (1 × 10–3 mol/L); then, it was ultrasonicated for 10 min to form uniform suspensions and the fluorescence spectra of different drugs were measured. The results show that the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu is significantly quenched in MDZ and TET, and the quenching efficiencies are up to 99.8 and 99.9%, respectively. For other drugs, the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu also decreased to different degrees ( and S10).

In order to detect the sensitivity of 1-Eu to MDZ and TET, the blank water samples were titrated with MDZ and TET, respectively, and the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu after each titration was recorded. The result indicates that the fluorescence intensity of 1-Eu decreases with the increase in the concentrations of MDZ and TET. The fluorescence of 1-Eu is completely quenched when TET and MDZ are at concentrations of 0.348 and 0.306 mM, respectively (a,b). According to Stern–Volmer (SV) equation (I 0/I = 1 + K sv [M]), it is possible to calculate quantitatively the quenching efficiency (I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after the addition of MDZ or TET, K sv is the quenching constant (M–1), and [M] is the concentration of MDZ or TET, respectively). The SV equation is used to determine the relationship between the concentration of MDZ or TET and fluorescence intensity. In the low-concentration range from 0 to 0.06 mM, the SV curve of MDZ or TET is virtually linearly connected. But the SV curve gradually deviates from the linear relationship with the increase in the antibiotic concentration (c,d). The nonlinear relationship of the SV curve may be attributed to energy transfer or the self-absorption of antibiotics. According to the fitting results, the K sv values of MDZ and TET are 1.5 × 104 and 1.45 × 104 M–1, respectively. Therefore, 1-Eu can be used as a promising fluorescent probe to detect MDZ and TET. According to the formula 3σ/K sv (σ is the standard deviation), the limit of detection (LOD) of MDZ and TET is 1.46 × 10–5 and 1.51 × 10–5 M, respectively, which are almost equivalent to those reported in the literature (Table S3).

Visual Detection of the Portable Test Paper Based on Smartphones

The paper sensor has the advantages of high practicability, low cost, and fast detection. Thus, it can be used for the identification and semi-quantitative detection of analytes. The prepared 1-Eu was used as a fluorescent probe to realize semi-quantitative detection of MDZ. The test strips were soaked in different concentrations of MDZ, and the red fluorescence of 1-Eu on the test strips was gradually quenched with the increase in concentration. Photos of test strips were taken with smartphones, and their RGB values were measured with the Color Picker software. In order to minimize the error, calibration curves were made between the red channel and MDZ concentrations after multiple readings. As shown in , with the increase of MDZ concentration, the color of the test paper gradually changes from bright pink to dark purple, and the value of B/R increases correspondingly, showing a good linear correlation (R 2 = 0.994). According to 3σ/slope, the LOD value of the detection limit is 14.7 ppm. Therefore, the paper sensor has potential application value in the rapid and sensitive detection of analytes.
cln_elements.clean_text:
X-ray Powder Diffraction and Thermogravimetric Analysis

The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) of 1-Ln and 1-Eu   x   Tb  1-x   is consistent with the simulated peaks, indicating that the duplicated samples are pure phase, which can be used for subsequent property exploration (Figure S3). 1-Ln was heated from 30 to 800 °C for thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in a N2 atmosphere. 1-Ln had similar thermal stability due to its isostructural properties, and 1-Eu was taken as an example to analyze in detail. The TGA of 1-Eu showed that weight loss was 31.3% (calcd 31.5%) between 35 and 309 °C, possibly attributed to the free solvent molecules and the coordinated water molecules being removed. The frame structure existed stably between 309 and 550 °C, then the frameworks collapsed (Figures S3c and S4).
